title: Good fences make good neighbors (with carnivores)

title_detail.value: Good fences make good neighbors (with carnivores)

summary: A new study has found that fortified enclosures also benefit nearby livestock keepers by preventing carnivore attacks.

summary_detail.value: A new study has found that fortified enclosures also benefit nearby livestock keepers by preventing carnivore attacks.

title: Combination of cosmic processes shapes the size and location of sub-Neptunes

title_detail.value: Combination of cosmic processes shapes the size and location of sub-Neptunes

summary: A combination of cosmic processes shapes the formation of one of the most common types of planets outside of our solar system, according to a new study.

summary_detail.value: A combination of cosmic processes shapes the formation of one of the most common types of planets outside of our solar system, according to a new study.

title: Age of upcoming asteroid flyby target

title_detail.value: Age of upcoming asteroid flyby target

summary: New modeling indicates the main belt asteroid (52246) Donaldjohanson may have formed about 150 million years ago when a larger parent asteroid broke apart; its orbit and spin properties have undergone significant evolution since. When NASA's Lucy spacecraft flies by this approximately three-mile-wide space rock on April 20, 2025, the data collected could provide independent insights on such processes based on its shape, surface geology and cratering history.

summary_detail.value: New modeling indicates the main belt asteroid (52246) Donaldjohanson may have formed about 150 million years ago when a larger parent asteroid broke apart; its orbit and spin properties have undergone significant evolution since. When NASA's Lucy spacecraft flies by this approximately three-mile-wide space rock on April 20, 2025, the data collected could provide independent insights on such processes based on its shape, surface geology and cratering history.

title: Psychological prehabilitation improves surgical recovery

title_detail.value: Psychological prehabilitation improves surgical recovery

summary: A new analysis led by surgeons finds that psychological prehabilitation can significantly enhance recovery after surgery. The study found that psychological prehabilitation significantly reduces the length of hospital stay, pain, anxiety, and depression after surgery.

summary_detail.value: A new analysis led by surgeons finds that psychological prehabilitation can significantly enhance recovery after surgery. The study found that psychological prehabilitation significantly reduces the length of hospital stay, pain, anxiety, and depression after surgery.

title: Neighborhood dispute among cells: Whichever successfully exerts force wins

title_detail.value: Neighborhood dispute among cells: Whichever successfully exerts force wins

summary: Trial of strength at the cellular level: Cells are in constant competition with each other and so eliminate diseased or unwanted cells. Cell competition is therefore a central principle for maintaining the health of tissues and organs. Researchers have investigated the success factors of superior cells and discovered a previously unknown winning strategy in mechanical cell competition. They identified a variety in the ability of cells to exert mechanical forces onto other cells as the decisive regulator.

Cell competition is therefore a central principle for maintaining the health of tissues and organs. Researchers have investigated the success factors of superior cells and discovered a previously unknown winning strategy in mechanical cell competition. They identified a variety in the ability of cells to exert mechanical forces onto other cells as the decisive regulator.

title: Unique dove species is the dodo of the Caribbean and in similar danger of dying out

title_detail.value: Unique dove species is the dodo of the Caribbean and in similar danger of dying out

summary: Ancient DNA shows an endangered dove species endemic to Cuba is more genetically distinct than the dodo was before it died out.

summary_detail.value: Ancient DNA shows an endangered dove species endemic to Cuba is more genetically distinct than the dodo was before it died out.

title: Twisting atomically thin materials could advance quantum computers

title_detail.value: Twisting atomically thin materials could advance quantum computers

summary: Researchers show that precisely layering nano-thin materials creates excitons -- essentially, artificial atoms -- that can act as quantum information bits, or qubits.

summary_detail.value: Researchers show that precisely layering nano-thin materials creates excitons -- essentially, artificial atoms -- that can act as quantum information bits, or qubits.

title: Maternal depression can lead to children's emotional overeating, study shows

title_detail.value: Maternal depression can lead to children's emotional overeating, study shows

summary: Up to 25% of new mothers suffer from postpartum depression, which can significantly impact their parenting behavior and the wellbeing of their children. A new study looks at long-term effects of early maternal depression on children, underscoring the need to provide adequate support for mothers who might be struggling.

summary_detail.value: Up to 25% of new mothers suffer from postpartum depression, which can significantly impact their parenting behavior and the wellbeing of their children. A new study looks at long-term effects of early maternal depression on children, underscoring the need to provide adequate support for mothers who might be struggling.

title: Slow, silent 'scream' of epithelial cells detected for first time

title_detail.value: Slow, silent 'scream' of epithelial cells detected for first time

summary: It has long been thought that only nerve and heart cells use electric impulses to communicate, while epithelial cells -- which compose the linings of our skin, organs and body cavities -- are mute, serving mostly as protective barriers that can absorb and secrete various substances. But researchers have now upended the status quo by showing that epithelial cells do indeed 'talk' to each other, albeit with slow electrical signals.

summary_detail.value: It has long been thought that only nerve and heart cells use electric impulses to communicate, while epithelial cells -- which compose the linings of our skin, organs and body cavities -- are mute, serving mostly as protective barriers that can absorb and secrete various substances. But researchers have now upended the status quo by showing that epithelial cells do indeed 'talk' to each other, albeit with slow electrical signals.

title: Iguanas floated one-fifth of the way around the world to colonize Fiji

title_detail.value: Iguanas floated one-fifth of the way around the world to colonize Fiji

summary: The only iguanas outside the Americas, Fiji iguanas are an enigma. A new genetic analysis shows that they are most closely related to the North American desert iguana, having separated about 34 million years ago, around the same time that the islands emerged from the sea. This suggests that the iguanas rafted 5,000 miles across the Pacific from western North America to reach Fiji -- the longest known transoceanic dispersal of any land animal.

summary_detail.value: The only iguanas outside the Americas, Fiji iguanas are an enigma. A new genetic analysis shows that they are most closely related to the North American desert iguana, having separated about 34 million years ago, around the same time that the islands emerged from the sea. This suggests that the iguanas rafted 5,000 miles across the Pacific from western North America to reach Fiji -- the longest known transoceanic dispersal of any land animal.

title: New clue on what is leading to neurodegenerative diseases like Alzheimer's and ALS

title_detail.value: New clue on what is leading to neurodegenerative diseases like Alzheimer's and ALS

summary: Researchers have revealed a new scientific clue that could unlock the key cellular pathway leading to devastating neurodegenerative diseases like Alzheimer's disease and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).

summary_detail.value: Researchers have revealed a new scientific clue that could unlock the key cellular pathway leading to devastating neurodegenerative diseases like Alzheimer's disease and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).

title: Immunotherapy may boost KRAS-targeted therapy in pancreatic cancer

title_detail.value: Immunotherapy may boost KRAS-targeted therapy in pancreatic cancer

summary: Adding immunotherapy to new KRAS inhibitors boosted responses in preclinical models, setting the stage for future trials of the combination strategy.

summary_detail.value: Adding immunotherapy to new KRAS inhibitors boosted responses in preclinical models, setting the stage for future trials of the combination strategy.

title: Scientists discover how to reactivate cancer's molecular 'kill switch'

title_detail.value: Scientists discover how to reactivate cancer's molecular 'kill switch'

summary: Researchers have discovered that cancer cells suppress 'poison exons' -- genetic elements that act as an off switch for protein production -- in a key gene called TRA2 , promoting tumor growth. By using antisense oligonucleotides (ASOs) to restore poison exon activity, the team effectively reactivated this kill switch, offering a potential new precision therapy for aggressive, hard-to-treat cancers.

summary_detail.value: Researchers have discovered that cancer cells suppress 'poison exons' -- genetic elements that act as an off switch for protein production -- in a key gene called TRA2 , promoting tumor growth. By using antisense oligonucleotides (ASOs) to restore poison exon activity, the team effectively reactivated this kill switch, offering a potential new precision therapy for aggressive, hard-to-treat cancers.

title: Scientists use light to unlock secret of atoms

title_detail.value: Scientists use light to unlock secret of atoms

summary: Researchers have developed innovative methods to control the ionization of atoms and molecules using specially structured light beams, challenging traditional limits. This breakthrough could lead to advancements in imaging, particle acceleration, and quantum computing by precisely controlling electron ejection from atoms.

summary_detail.value: Researchers have developed innovative methods to control the ionization of atoms and molecules using specially structured light beams, challenging traditional limits. This breakthrough could lead to advancements in imaging, particle acceleration, and quantum computing by precisely controlling electron ejection from atoms.

title: 'Microlightning' in water droplets may have sparked life on Earth

title_detail.value: 'Microlightning' in water droplets may have sparked life on Earth

summary: A study shows that electrical charges in sprays of water can cause chemical reactions that form organic molecules from inorganic materials. The findings provide evidence that microlightning may have helped create the building blocks necessary for early life on the planet.

summary_detail.value: A study shows that electrical charges in sprays of water can cause chemical reactions that form organic molecules from inorganic materials. The findings provide evidence that microlightning may have helped create the building blocks necessary for early life on the planet.

title: Smoke from wildland-urban interface fires more deadly than remote wildfires

title_detail.value: Smoke from wildland-urban interface fires more deadly than remote wildfires

summary: New research quantifies the health risks of wildland-urban interface fires, showing fire emissions in populated areas are three times more likely to lead to annual premature deaths than emissions from wildfires in general.

summary_detail.value: New research quantifies the health risks of wildland-urban interface fires, showing fire emissions in populated areas are three times more likely to lead to annual premature deaths than emissions from wildfires in general.

title: Proteins and pathways involved in inflammation are associated with changes in bone mineral density over time

title_detail.value: Proteins and pathways involved in inflammation are associated with changes in bone mineral density over time

summary: Researchers have found that proteins and pathways involved in inflammation are associated with changes in bone mineral density (BMD) over time. The research, could potentially lead to the identification of biomarkers that would serve as early indicators of a person's risk for bone health issues later in life.

title: Pacific island water security requires new approach

title_detail.value: Pacific island water security requires new approach

summary: Hydrology experts are calling for urgent investigations into the operation of bore-fields that access fresh groundwater on Pacific islands, including Kiribati, where rising sea levels are already putting local water supplies at risk.

summary_detail.value: Hydrology experts are calling for urgent investigations into the operation of bore-fields that access fresh groundwater on Pacific islands, including Kiribati, where rising sea levels are already putting local water supplies at risk.

title: Artificial photosynthesis: Researchers mimic plants

title_detail.value: Artificial photosynthesis: Researchers mimic plants

summary: With artificial photosynthesis, humankind could utilize solar energy to bind carbon dioxide and produce hydrogen. Chemists have taken this one step further: They have synthesized a stack of dyes that comes very close to the photosynthetic apparatus of plants. It absorbs light energy, uses it to separate charge carriers and transfers them quickly and efficiently in the stack.

Chemists have taken this one step further: They have synthesized a stack of dyes that comes very close to the photosynthetic apparatus of plants. It absorbs light energy, uses it to separate charge carriers and transfers them quickly and efficiently in the stack.

title: Quantum spin model made from nanographene molecules

title_detail.value: Quantum spin model made from nanographene molecules

summary: Researchers have experimentally recreated another fundamental theoretical model from quantum physics, which goes back to the Nobel Prize laureate Werner Heisenberg. The basis for the successful experiment is made of tiny carbon molecules known as nanographenes. This synthetic bottom-up approach enables versatile experimental research into quantum technologies, which could one day help drive breakthroughs in the field.

The basis for the successful experiment is made of tiny carbon molecules known as nanographenes. This synthetic bottom-up approach enables versatile experimental research into quantum technologies, which could one day help drive breakthroughs in the field.

title: Understanding the origin of magnetic moment enhancement in novel alloys

title_detail.value: Understanding the origin of magnetic moment enhancement in novel alloys

summary: Iridium-doped iron-cobalt (Fe-Co-Ir) alloys, previously identified through machine learning, have been shown to have enhanced magnetic properties, surpassing even the widely used pure Fe-Co alloy. However, the origin of this enhanced magnetization is poorly understood. Now, scientists employed an innovative method using high-throughput X-ray magnetic circular dichroism (XMCD) measurements, demonstrating the critical role of Ir-doping. The findings will serve as a foundation for designing new high-performance magnetic materials.

title: TOI-1453: Sub-Neptune in system of two exoplanets

title_detail.value: TOI-1453: Sub-Neptune in system of two exoplanets

summary: Astronomers have discovered two exoplanets around TOI-1453, a star about 250 light years away. These two exoplanets, a super-Earth and a sub-Neptune, are common in the galaxy, yet are absent from our system. This discovery paves the way for future atmospheric studies to better understand these types of planets.

summary_detail.value: Astronomers have discovered two exoplanets around TOI-1453, a star about 250 light years away. These two exoplanets, a super-Earth and a sub-Neptune, are common in the galaxy, yet are absent from our system. This discovery paves the way for future atmospheric studies to better understand these types of planets.

title: Researchers develop computational tools to safeguard privacy without degrading voice-based cognitive markers

title_detail.value: Researchers develop computational tools to safeguard privacy without degrading voice-based cognitive markers

summary: Digital voice recordings contain valuable information that can indicate an individual's cognitive health, offering a non-invasive and efficient method for assessment. Research has demonstrated that digital voice measures can detect early signs of cognitive decline by analyzing features such as speech rate, articulation, pitch variation and pauses, which may signal cognitive impairment when deviating from normative patterns. However, voice data introduces privacy challenges due to the personally identifiable information embedded in recordings, such as gender, accent and emotional state, as well as more subtle speech characteristics that can uniquely identify individuals. These risks are amplified when voice data is processed by automated systems, raising concerns about re-identification and potential misuse of data.

Research has demonstrated that digital voice measures can detect early signs of cognitive decline by analyzing features such as speech rate, articulation, pitch variation and pauses, which may signal cognitive impairment when deviating from normative patterns. title: Not knowing what to expect can make pain feel worse

title_detail.value: Not knowing what to expect can make pain feel worse

summary: When the brain doesn't know what to expect we perceive pain to be worse, a new study shows. The study may help shape more effective ways to manage pain in the future.

summary_detail.value: When the brain doesn't know what to expect we perceive pain to be worse, a new study shows. The study may help shape more effective ways to manage pain in the future.

title: Oxytocin system of breastfeeding affected in mothers with postnatal depression

title_detail.value: Oxytocin system of breastfeeding affected in mothers with postnatal depression

summary: The oxytocin system -- which helps release breast milk and strengthens the bond between mother and baby -- may be affected during breastfeeding in mothers experiencing postnatal depression.

summary_detail.value: The oxytocin system -- which helps release breast milk and strengthens the bond between mother and baby -- may be affected during breastfeeding in mothers experiencing postnatal depression.

title: New members of the CDKL family of genes linked to neurodevelopmental disorders

title_detail.value: New members of the CDKL family of genes linked to neurodevelopmental disorders

summary: Researchers have deepened our understanding of two of the five members of the CDKL family of genes, CDKL2 and CDKL1. They show that variants in these genes can lead to neurodevelopmental conditions, including epilepsy, and propose a mechanism by which the defective variants may cause the neurological symptoms in affected individuals.

summary_detail.value: Researchers have deepened our understanding of two of the five members of the CDKL family of genes, CDKL2 and CDKL1. They show that variants in these genes can lead to neurodevelopmental conditions, including epilepsy, and propose a mechanism by which the defective variants may cause the neurological symptoms in affected individuals.

title: Cellular circuit controls how DNA damage is repaired, affecting risk of disease as we age

title_detail.value: Cellular circuit controls how DNA damage is repaired, affecting risk of disease as we age

summary: New findings show that the mitochondria powering our cells also control the ability of a DNA repair protein to suppress the senescence-associated secretory phenotype (SASP), which causes zombie-like cells to spew inflammatory molecules that can contribute to chronic inflammation in the body.

summary_detail.value: New findings show that the mitochondria powering our cells also control the ability of a DNA repair protein to suppress the senescence-associated secretory phenotype (SASP), which causes zombie-like cells to spew inflammatory molecules that can contribute to chronic inflammation in the body.

title: How chemistry and force etch mysterious spiral patterns on solid surfaces

title_detail.value: How chemistry and force etch mysterious spiral patterns on solid surfaces

summary: Curiosity about a mistake that left tiny dots on a germanium wafer with evaporated metal films led to the discovery of beautiful spiral patterns etched on the surface of the semiconductor by a chemical reaction. Further experiments showed that the patterns arise from chemical reactions that are coupled to mechanical forces through the deformation of a catalyzing agent. The new system is the first major advance in experimental methods to study chemical pattern formation since the 1950s. Studying these complex systems will help scientists understand other natural processes, from crack formation in materials to how stress influences biological growth.

Further experiments showed that the patterns arise from chemical reactions that are coupled to mechanical forces through the deformation of a catalyzing agent. The new system is the first major advance in experimental methods to study chemical pattern formation since the 1950s. Studying these complex systems will help scientists understand other natural processes, from crack formation in materials to how stress influences biological growth.

title: Mother's high-fat diet can cause liver stress in fetus

title_detail.value: Mother's high-fat diet can cause liver stress in fetus

summary: When mothers eat a diet high in fat and sugars, their unborn babies can develop liver stress that continues into early life. A new study sheds light on changes to the fetus's bile acid, which affects how liver disease develops and progresses.

summary_detail.value: When mothers eat a diet high in fat and sugars, their unborn babies can develop liver stress that continues into early life. A new study sheds light on changes to the fetus's bile acid, which affects how liver disease develops and progresses.

title: Weighing in on a Mars water debate

title_detail.value: Weighing in on a Mars water debate

summary: Water once existed in abundance of at the surface of Mars. How much of that water has been stored in the planet's crust is still unclear, according to a new analysis.

summary_detail.value: Water once existed in abundance of at the surface of Mars. How much of that water has been stored in the planet's crust is still unclear, according to a new analysis.

title: Older adults might be more resistant to bird flu infections than children

title_detail.value: Older adults might be more resistant to bird flu infections than children

summary: Older adults who were exposed to seasonal flu viruses that circulated prior to 1968 are more likely to have some protection against H5N1, and children would benefit more from H5N1 vaccines.

summary_detail.value: Older adults who were exposed to seasonal flu viruses that circulated prior to 1968 are more likely to have some protection against H5N1, and children would benefit more from H5N1 vaccines.

title: As next hurricane season nears, study explores impacts of 2024's storms

title_detail.value: As next hurricane season nears, study explores impacts of 2024's storms

summary: When major storms hit Houston last spring and summer, losing power was a nightmare for residents, but for many, the financial fallout was just as devastating. A new report finds that more than half of Houston-area workers lost income due to these storms, either because they couldn't get to work or their jobs were forced to close.

title: Lowering bioenergetic age may help fend off Alzheimer's

title_detail.value: Lowering bioenergetic age may help fend off Alzheimer's

summary: A person's 'bioenergetic age' -- or how youthfully their cells generate energy -- might be a key indicator of whether they're at risk of developing Alzheimer's disease, new research shows. The study suggests healthy living can turn back the bioenergetic clock for some people, helping them fend off Alzheimer's as effectively as a new drug called lecanemab.

The study suggests healthy living can turn back the bioenergetic clock for some people, helping them fend off Alzheimer's as effectively as a new drug called lecanemab.

title: Chocolate -- with potential health benefits

title_detail.value: Chocolate -- with potential health benefits

summary: Many people will soon load up Easter baskets with chocolate candy for children and adults to enjoy. On its own, dark chocolate has health benefits, such as antioxidants that neutralize damaging free radicals. And a new report suggests that packing the sweet treat with pre- and probiotics could make it more healthful. Flavoring agents, however, can affect many properties, including moisture level and protein content of the chocolate product.

title_detail.value: When it comes to ACL injury, a dollar of prevention is worth more than seven dollars of cure

title_detail.value: Misha lived in zoos, but the elephant's tooth enamel helps reconstruct wildlife migrations

summary: Misha lived her whole life in zoos, but this elephant's teeth are now helping scientists reconstruct wildlife migrations. Geologists show how strontium isotopes found in teeth or tusks reveal where large plant-eating animals may have roamed.

title: Scientists solve decades-long Parkinson's mystery

title_detail.value: Scientists solve decades-long Parkinson's mystery

summary: Researchers have made a huge leap forward in the fight against Parkinson's disease, solving a decades-long mystery. In a major breakthrough, they have been able to see the human PINK1 protein and how it is switched on for the first time. The discovery is a significant milestone in Parkinson's research that paves the way for developing new life-changing drugs.

title: Spinning, twisted light could power next-generation electronics

title_detail.value: Spinning, twisted light could power next-generation electronics

summary: Researchers have advanced a decades-old challenge in the field of organic semiconductors, opening new possibilities for the future of electronics. The researchers have created an organic semiconductor that forces electrons to move in a spiral pattern, which could improve the efficiency of OLED displays in television and smartphone screens, or power next-generation computing technologies such as spintronics and quantum computing.

title: Detailed map of dust in the Milky Way

title_detail.value: Detailed map of dust in the Milky Way

summary: Astronomers have constructed the first detailed 3D map of the properties of cosmic dust in our home galaxy. For their map, the astronomers used 130 million spectra from ESA's Gaia mission, results from the LAMOST spectral survey, and machine learning. Dust makes distant astronomical objects appear more reddish and dimmer than they really are, so the new map will be an important tool for astronomers to make sense of their observations. The study has also revealed unusual properties of cosmic dust that will lead to further research.

title: Re-purposed FDA-approved drug could help treat high-grade glioma

title_detail.value: Re-purposed FDA-approved drug could help treat high-grade glioma

summary: A study shows that high-grade glioma tumor cells harboring DNA alterations in the gene PDGFRA responded to the drug avapritinib, which is already approved by the United States Food and Drug Administration to treat gastrointestinal stromal tumors with a PDGFRA exon 18 mutation as well advanced systemic mastocytosis and indolent systemic mastocytosis.

title: New name for one of the world's rarest rhinoceroses

title_detail.value: New name for one of the world's rarest rhinoceroses

summary: A recent study has reclassified the species commonly known as the Javan rhinoceros, proposing a more precise scientific name: Eurhinoceros sondaicus. The research highlights key differences in body structure and ecology that set this species apart from the Indian rhinoceros (Rhinoceros unicornis). Recognizing it as a separate genus not only improves scientific understanding but also has important implications for conservation efforts.

title: The long wait for bees to return to restored grasslands

title_detail.value: The long wait for bees to return to restored grasslands

summary: Recovered grasslands need more than 75 years of continuous management to regain their biodiversity because specialized pollinators are slow to return. A new finding underscores the importance of preserving old grasslands as reservoirs of biodiversity, even if it is just as ski slopes.

summary_detail.value: Recovered grasslands need more than 75 years of continuous management to regain their biodiversity because specialized pollinators are slow to return. A new finding underscores the importance of preserving old grasslands as reservoirs of biodiversity, even if it is just as ski slopes.

title: Breakthrough nano-spring technology boosts battery durability and energy density

title_detail.value: Breakthrough nano-spring technology boosts battery durability and energy density

summary: Scientists improved battery durability and energy density with a nano-spring coating.

summary_detail.value: Scientists improved battery durability and energy density with a nano-spring coating.

title: Quantum-inspired cameras capture the start of life

title_detail.value: Quantum-inspired cameras capture the start of life

summary: Researchers have performed the first imaging of embryos using cameras designed for quantum measurements. The academics investigated how to best use ultrasensitive camera technology, including the latest generation of cameras that can count individual packets of light energy at each pixel, for life sciences.

summary_detail.value: Researchers have performed the first imaging of embryos using cameras designed for quantum measurements. The academics investigated how to best use ultrasensitive camera technology, including the latest generation of cameras that can count individual packets of light energy at each pixel, for life sciences.

title: Focus on the gut-liver axis: Semisynthetic bile acid has anti-inflammatory effects on the gut

title_detail.value: Focus on the gut-liver axis: Semisynthetic bile acid has anti-inflammatory effects on the gut

summary: A research team has made further progress in the treatment of intestinal inflammation. A study shows that the semi-synthetic bile acid NorUDCA inhibits in the intestine the formation of pro-inflammatory T helper 17 cells (TH17) and at the same time promotes the generation of anti-inflammatory regulatory T cells. This could be a promising new therapeutic option for patients with TH17-mediated intestinal diseases.

summary_detail.value: A research team has made further progress in the treatment of intestinal inflammation. A study shows that the semi-synthetic bile acid NorUDCA inhibits in the intestine the formation of pro-inflammatory T helper 17 cells (TH17) and at the same time promotes the generation of anti-inflammatory regulatory T cells. This could be a promising new therapeutic option for patients with TH17-mediated intestinal diseases.

title: Antigenic variation: Decoding the mechanism controlling antigen activation in trypanosomes

title_detail.value: Antigenic variation: Decoding the mechanism controlling antigen activation in trypanosomes

summary: A new study shows how pathogens control changes in their cell surface to evade the immune system.

summary_detail.value: A new study shows how pathogens control changes in their cell surface to evade the immune system.

title: The relationship between gut microbiota, immunoglobulin A, and vaccine efficacy

title_detail.value: The relationship between gut microbiota, immunoglobulin A, and vaccine efficacy

summary: A study has established the importance of immunoglobulin A, an antibody that is part of the immune system, in generating a response to pneumonia vaccines. Researchers have found that the absence of this antibody leads to an overgrowth of gut microbiota, triggering an excessive and sustained immune system response, which ultimately becomes exhausted and fails to respond effectively to vaccines.

summary_detail.value: A study has established the importance of immunoglobulin A, an antibody that is part of the immune system, in generating a response to pneumonia vaccines. Researchers have found that the absence of this antibody leads to an overgrowth of gut microbiota, triggering an excessive and sustained immune system response, which ultimately becomes exhausted and fails to respond effectively to vaccines.

title: Nature relieves physical pain: pain-related signals in the brain are reduced

title_detail.value: Nature relieves physical pain: pain-related signals in the brain are reduced

summary: Neuroscientists have shown that experiencing nature can alleviate acute physical pain. Surprisingly, simply watching nature videos was enough to relieve pain. Using functional magnetic resonance imaging, the researchers found that acute pain was rated as less intense and unpleasant when watching nature videos -- along with a reduction in brain activity associated with pain. The results suggest that nature-based therapies can be used as promising complementary approaches to pain management.

summary_detail.value: Neuroscientists have shown that experiencing nature can alleviate acute physical pain. Surprisingly, simply watching nature videos was enough to relieve pain. Using functional magnetic resonance imaging, the researchers found that acute pain was rated as less intense and unpleasant when watching nature videos -- along with a reduction in brain activity associated with pain. The results suggest that nature-based therapies can be used as promising complementary approaches to pain management.

title: How industrial waste gases could replace fossil fuels in everyday consumer products

title_detail.value: How industrial waste gases could replace fossil fuels in everyday consumer products

summary: Industrial waste gases, long seen as a major contributor to climate change, could soon be captured and repurposed into everyday household products such as shampoo, detergent, and even fuel.

summary_detail.value: Industrial waste gases, long seen as a major contributor to climate change, could soon be captured and repurposed into everyday household products such as shampoo, detergent, and even fuel.

title: Depressing findings for those suffering from eating disorders

title_detail.value: Depressing findings for those suffering from eating disorders

summary: New research shows that people with eating disorders are more harshly judged than those suffering from depression, making it much harder for them to seek treatment.

summary_detail.value: New research shows that people with eating disorders are more harshly judged than those suffering from depression, making it much harder for them to seek treatment.

title: Most current AI struggles to read clocks and calendars

title_detail.value: Most current AI struggles to read clocks and calendars

summary: Some of the world's most advanced AI systems struggle to tell the time and work out dates on calendars, a study suggests.
